title: Drep-2 is a novel synaptic protein important for learning and memory
abstract: CIDE-N domains mediate interactions between the DNase Dff40/CAD and its inhibitor Dff45/ICAD. In this study, we report that the CIDE-N protein Drep-2 is a novel synaptic protein important for learning and behavioral adaptation. Drep-2 was found at synapses throughout the <italic>Drosophila</italic> brain and was strongly enriched at mushroom body input synapses. It was required within Kenyon cells for normal olfactory short- and intermediate-term memory. Drep-2 colocalized with metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs). Chronic pharmacological stimulation of mGluRs compensated for <italic>drep-2</italic> learning deficits, and <italic>drep-2</italic> and <italic>mGluR</italic> learning phenotypes behaved non-additively, suggesting that Drep 2 might be involved in effective mGluR signaling. In fact, <italic>Drosophila</italic> fragile X protein mutants, shown to benefit from attenuation of mGluR signaling, profited from the elimination of <italic>drep-2</italic>. Thus, Drep-2 is a novel regulatory synaptic factor, probably intersecting with metabotropic signaling and translational regulation.
